shortTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bearish events outweigh bullish events.

intermediateTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bearish events outweigh bullish events.

msBullishSummary: Simon's access to capital, scale, and validated record position the firm to execute on any attractive and available investment opportunities.

Simon's high-quality portfolio will continue to present attractive locations for tenants to place stores, even as retail companies look to reduce store counts, and present the most desirable locations for e-tailers looking to establish a physical presence.
Simon’s mall and outlet portfolio contains a high percentage of the best malls in the country, where redevelopment capital can be deployed at the most promising yields.
msBearishSummary: If consumers forced to purchase goods online during the coronavirus crisis permanently change their behavior to favor e-commerce and avoid public places, long-term sales growth could suffer.

Retailers are looking to reduce store counts and average store size, so Simon may need to make significant concessions to keep existing tenants and attract new tenants to fill both in-line and anchor spaces.
Given the relative maturity of the US retail market and the size of the company, Simon may be encouraged to seek larger, riskier investments domestically and abroad to move the needle.

researchReports.title: Following Two Years of Rising Interest Rates, We Believe REITs Are Trading at Significant Discounts
researchReports.summary: Simon Property Group is the second-largest real estate investment trust in the United States. Its portfolio includes an interest in 230 properties: 136 traditional malls, 69 premium outlets, 14 Mills centers (a combination of a traditional mall, outlet center, and big-box retailers), 6 lifestyle centers, and 5 other retail properties. Simon's portfolio averaged $743 in sales per square foot in 2023 compared with $693 in sales per square foot over the 12 months before the pandemic. The company also owns a 21% interest in Klépierre, a European retail company with investments in shopping centers in 16 countries, and joint-venture interests in 33 premium outlets across 11 countries.

reports.headHtml: The Argus High-Yield Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Value stocks -- a market segment that includes high-yield stocks -- outperformed growth stocks in 2022. That's a recent rarity, as for the past decade-plus, the performance record has favored growth. But the tide turned in 2022. The rollout of COVID-19 vaccines gave a lift to some of the cyclical companies (energy and regional banks) that had lagged in recent quarters, and value stocks outpaced growth stocks that year. While growth stocks have retaken the lead since 2023, the Federal Reserve continues to keep interest rates high to fend off inflation. This could possibly cap multiple expansion for growth companies in coming quarters. In any event, the value sector is the place to achieve income.

reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: Value stocks -- a market segment that includes high-yield stocks -- outperformed growth stocks in 2022. That's a recent rarity, as for more than a decade, the performance record favored growth. Since 2010, the Russell 1000 Growth Index has climbed more than 575%, compared to an advance of almost 200% for the Russell 1000 Value Index. In 10 of the past 13 years, growth stocks have topped value stocks.  That hasn't always been the case. In the 2000-2010 decade, including the Great Recession, value stocks were better performers than growth stocks, advancing an admittedly low 8% (but still better than growth, which declined 15% during the decade). Value investors trace their roots to the famous "Security Analysis" textbook, written by Ben Graham, an economics professor at Columbia University.  Warren Buffett was one of his students. Why the recent deviation in performance? Several reasons, including changes in the make-up of the economy, growth in intangible assets, and the current level of interest rates. But the tide turned back in 2022, at least for a while, as the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines gave a lift to some of the cyclical companies (energy and regional banks) that had lagged in recent years. While growth stocks have recaptured the lead since 2023, the Federal Reserve continues to keep interest rates high to fend off inflation. This could possibly cap multiple expansion for growth companies in coming quarters. In any event, the value sector is the place to achieve income. The current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Value Index ETF is 2.0%, compared to the 0.7% current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Growth Index ETF. For our list this week, we have screened our coverage universe for stocks that are BUY-rated by Argus Research analysts, have an Argus Financial Strength Rating of at least Medium, and have a yield of 3.0% or higher. Here's a baker's dozen that meet the criteria. These stocks are also featured in our High-Yield theme model portfolio.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Simon Property Group, Inc.
reports.reportTitle:
Simon Property Group Inc., based in Indianapolis, is a retail REIT that is one of the largest owners of high-end malls, outlet centers, and lifestyle destinations in North America, Asia, and Europe. The company has expanded its profile by investing in the retail operations of several well-known retail brands, including JC Penny (with partner Brookfield) and Authentic Brands Group (with partner SPARC). ABG brands include Aeropostale, Reebok, Nautica, Izod, and Forever 21. SPG has a 33% interest in SPARC. Additionally, the company has an 84% interest in the Taubman Group and a 22% interest in Klepierre, a Paris-based real estate firm. SPG also operates Simon Brand Ventures, which offers appraisals and real estate services. 

Simon owns or has interests in about 250 properties with 195 million square feet of leasable space. This includes 35 international properties. Joint Ventures accounted for about 60% of 2023 revenues. U.S. malls and outlets account for approximately 72% of NOI and international assets account for about 9%. Properties in California, Florida, and Texas account for about 43% of U.S. NOI. Recent development activity includes the construction of a lifestyle center in Atlanta and premium outlets in Tokyo, Jakarta, and South Korea. 

The REIT has a varied tenant base. Its top tenants are Gap Inc., Tapestry, and Signet Jewelers, although their leases account for about 6% of total base minimum rent. SPG is a member of the S&P 500 and has a market cap of $47 billion.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: ASH, CAH, CL, FCX, HOG, SPG, TROW, HLT, PYPL
reports.reportTitle: U.S. equities inched higher on Thursday despite regional bank woes and ahead of the CPI revisions that will be released this morning. After hitting 5000 for the first time ever, the S&P 500 closed just below 5000. The Dow also closed at an all-time high. Big stock gainers include Arm Holdings PLC (ARM), up 48% and Ralph Lauren Corp. (RL), up 25%. The S&P 500 closed up less than 0.1%, the Dow was up 0.1% and the Nasdaq gained 0.2%. Crude oil rose above $76 per barrel and gold was up $1 to $2049 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Simon Property Group, Inc.
reports.reportTitle:
Simon Property Group Inc., based in Indianapolis, is a retail REIT that is one of the largest owners of high-end malls, outlet centers, and lifestyle destinations in North America, Asia, and Europe. The company has expanded its profile by investing in the retail operations of several well-known brands, including JC Penny and SPARC (Aeropostale, Reebok, Nautica, Izod, and Forever 21). SPG has a 33% interest in SPARC and ABG. Additionally, the company has an 84% interest in the Taubman Group and a 22% interest in Klepierre, a Paris-based real estate firm. SPG also operates Simon Brand Ventures, which offers appraisals and real estate services. Joint Ventures currently account for about 60% of revenues.

Simon owns or has interests in about 250 properties with 195 million square feet of leasable space. U.S. malls and outlets account for approximately 72% of NOI and international assets account for about 9%. Properties in California, Florida, and Texas account for about 42% of U.S. NOI. Recent development activity includes construction of a lifestyle center in Atlanta and premium outlets in Tokyo, Jakarta, and South Korea. 

The REIT has a varied tenant base. Its largest U.S. tenants are Gap Inc., Signet Jewelers, and Luxottica Group, although their leases account for less than 6% of total base minimum rent. SPG is a member of the S&P 500 and has a market cap of $38 billion.

reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: Value stocks -- a market segment that includes high-yield stocks -- outperformed growth stocks in 2022 for the first time since 2016. Indeed, for the past decade, the performance record has favored growth. Since 2010, the Russell 1000 Growth Index has climbed more than 550%, compared to an advance of almost 300% for the Russell 1000 Value Index. In eight of the past 10 years, growth stocks have topped value stocks. That hasn't always been the case. In the 2000-2010 decade, which included two Bear Markets and the Great Recession, value stocks were better performers than growth stocks, advancing an admittedly low 8% -- but still better than growth, which declined 15% during the decade. Value investors trace their roots to the famous "Security Analysis" textbook, written in 1934 (the year Argus Research was founded) by Ben Graham, an economics professor at Columbia University. Warren Buffett was one of his students. Looking ahead, the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines has given a lift to some of the cyclical companies (Energy sector companies in particular) that have lagged in recent years, and value stocks outpaced growth stocks in the past year. Now, the Federal Reserve is lifting interest rates to fend off inflation, which likely will cap multiple expansion for growth companies. In any event, value is the place to achieve income. The current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Value Index ETF is 2.0%, compared to the 0.7% current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Growth Index ETF. For our list this week, we screened our coverage universe for stocks that are BUY-rated by Argus Research analysts, have an Argus Financial Strength rating of at least Medium, and have a yield of 3.0% or higher.  Here's a baker's dozen of stocks that meet the criteria.

reports.reportTitle: Value stocks -- a market segment that includes high-yield stocks -- outperformed growth stocks in 2022 for the first time since 2016. Indeed, for the past decade, the performance record has favored growth. But the tide turned in 2022. The rollout of COVID-19 vaccines gave a lift to some of the cyclical companies (energy companies and regional banks) that had lagged in recent quarters, and value stocks outpaced growth stocks over the past year. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve continues to lift interest rates to fend off inflation, which could possibly cap multiple expansion for growth companies for a few more quarters. Regardless, the value sector is the place to achieve income. The current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Value Index ETF is 2.2%, compared to the 0.9% current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Growth Index ETF.  For our High-Yield Theme Model Portfolio, we are seeking stocks with yields of at least 3.0%.  This moves us deep into the value segment of the market.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Simon Property Group, Inc.
reports.reportTitle:
Simon Property Group Inc., based in Indianapolis, is a retail REIT that is one of the largest owners of high-end malls, outlet centers, and lifestyle destinations in North America, Asia, and Europe. The company has expanded its profile by investing in the retail operations of several well-known brands, including JC Penny and SPARC (Aeropostale, Reebok, Nautica, Izod, and Forever 21). NOI from these retail investments is approximately 8% of total NOI. SPG also operates Simon Brand Ventures, which offers appraisals and real estate services.

Simon owns or has interests in 235 properties with 195 million square feet of leasable space. U.S. malls and outlets account for approximately 72% of NOI. Properties in California, Florida, and Texas account for just under half of the portfolio. Additionally, the company has an 80% interest in the Taubman Group and a 22% interest in Klepierre, a Paris-based real estate firm. Recent development activity includes construction of a lifestyle center in Atlanta and premium outlets in Tokyo and South Korea. 

The REIT has a varied tenant base.  Its largest U.S. tenant, Gap Inc., leases almost 300 locations, but accounts for less than 3% of base minimum rents. SPG is a member of the S&P 500 and has a market cap of $38.2 billion.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: SPG, TGT, BCE, UWMC
reports.reportTitle: Stocks edged lower on Thursday morning after giving up early gains. The decline followed a selloff on Wednesday after the Fed's latest meeting minutes indicated that the central bank remained focused on controlling inflation and suggested that further rate hikes were possible at upcoming meetings. On the earnings front, Cisco shares rose 4% after the company reported better-than-expected fiscal 4Q results, while Walmart shares fell despite strong second-quarter sales and earnings and an increase in its full-year EPS guidance. The Dow fell 0.1%, the S&P 0.1%, and the Nasdaq 0.4%. Crude oil rose 2% to $81 per barrel, while gold fell $6 to $1923 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: CB, AVY, TT, J, NOC, SAP, SPG, SPH, SWKS, WM, KKR
reports.reportTitle: We are raising our intermediate-term technical outlook back to bullish from neutral. After breaking out of a bullish cup formation on February 1, and above chart resistance from the prior highs at 4,100, the S&P 500 (SPX) pulled right back to that level on Monday and again on an intraday basis on Tuesday. The index also fell right to short-term trendline support off the lows since January 20. The result was a picture-perfect bullish backtest of support and a very strong bounce.

reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: Insiders Sentiment Positive As Year End Approaches
reports.reportTitle: As earnings season began in mid-October, insider sentiment was solidly positive and we wrote the following: "Insiders just won't give in to the dire mood on Wall Street." Over the next four weeks, insider-sentiment gauges from Vickers Stock Research became less meaningful as insiders were broadly prohibited from trading during earnings season. Now, with earnings season drawing to a close and insiders starting to trade again, the rubber meets the road.  Have insiders turned cautious or is their trading activity showing the enthusiasm that was in place ahead of earnings? Vickers' current short-term data (one-week) has calmed noticeably after a negative low-volume spike last week. Vickers' long-term data (eight-weeks) also is positive, with 11 of 16 recent measurements bullish and five neutral. Finally, the characteristics of this week's data are positive. The total number of insider sales transactions this week is down 16% since last week, while the total number of purchase transactions is up 28%. Heading into the final weeks of 2022, insiders are telling us that stocks seem well positioned to claw back more of the year-to-date losses. On a sector basis, buying activity was strongest last week in Technology and Real Estate. Selling activity was strongest in Consumer Discretionary.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: HWM, DHI, ITGR, PXD, SPG, XOM, BRK/B
reports.reportTitle: Stocks soared on Thursday morning after lower-than-expected inflation data raised prospects for a slowdown in Federal Reserve rate hikes. The Labor Department said that its core consumer price index, excluding food and energy costs, rose 6.3% from the prior year in October, down from 6.6% in September and below the Bloomberg consensus forecast of 6.5% growth. The Dow jumped 2.7%, the S&P 4.1%, and the Nasdaq 6.1%. Crude oil rose to $87 per barrel, while gold rose $33 to $1747 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: ALB, SPG, WYNN, UL, WBD, APTV, RITM
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rose modestly on Monday morning, led by the Consumer Staples sector, after recovering from early losses. Chinese economic data was weak, as retail sales and industrial output both fell in July and missed consensus forecasts. On the housing front, the National Association of Home Builders said that its homebuilder sentiment index fell to 49 in August, down from 55 in July and the eighth straight monthly decline. The Dow rose 0.3%, the S&P 0.2%, and the Nasdaq 0.4%. Crude oil fell $3 to $89 per barrel, while gold fell $20 to $1796 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CAH, CSCO, SHEL, SPG, TGT, LULU
reports.reportTitle: Stocks were mixed in volatile trading on Thursday morning, a day after Wednesday's sharp selloff, as the S&P continued to approach bear-market levels. Cisco shares fell 13%, despite above-consensus earnings, after the company offered disappointing guidance for the current fiscal fourth quarter. Kohl's also cut its full-year sales and earnings guidance, though the shares rose more than 2% after dropping sharply in the retail selloff on Wednesday. The Dow fell 0.7%, the S&P fell 0.2%, and the Nasdaq rose 1.2%. Crude oil rose slightly to $110 per barrel, while gold rose $31 to $1847 per ounce.

reports.reportTitle: Value stocks -- a market segment that includes high-yield stocks -- are outperforming growth stocks in 2022. For the past decade, the performance record has favored growth. Since 2010, the Russell 1000 Growth Index has climbed more than 600%, compared to an advance of 300% for the Russell 1000 Value Index. In nine of the past 10 years, growth stocks have topped value stocks. That hasn't always been the case. In the 2000-2010 decade, including the Great Recession, value stocks were better performers than growth stocks, advancing an admittedly low 8% -- but still better than growth, which declined 15% during the decade. Value investors trace their roots to the famous "Security Analysis" textbook, written by Ben Graham, an economics professor at Columbia University. Warren Buffett was one of his students. The rollout of COVID-19 vaccines has given a lift to some of the cyclical companies (energy firms and regional banks) that have lagged in recent quarters, and value stocks have kept up the pace with growth stocks in the past year.  Now, the Federal Reserve is poised to lift interest rates to fend off high inflation, which will likely cap multiple expansion for growth companies. reports.headHtml: Market Update: BHP, DVN, SPG, VMC, WMT
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell again on Friday morning amid continued concerns about the deepening crisis in Ukraine and the impact of approaching Fed rate hikes. Housing data was positive. The National Association of Realtors said that U.S. existing home sales rose 6.7% in January to an annualized 6.5 million, well above the Bloomberg consensus forecast of 6.1 million. The Dow fell 0.4%, the S&P 0.5%, and the Nasdaq 1.0%. Crude oil fell to $91 per barrel, while gold traded near $1895 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: Insiders Pounce
reports.reportTitle: In response to market volatility last week, corporate insiders absolutely jumped on the opportunity to buy lower-priced stocks. All of the one-week sell/buy ratios from Vickers Stock Research -- across all exchanges -- powered into bullish territory with readings that were below 2.0. Such unanimity has not occurred since May of 2020 at the outset of the pandemic, and offers a rare, broad-based bullish signal from corporate executives, directors, and beneficial owners. For reference, Vickers considers a sell/buy reading of 2.0-2.5 to be neutral, with readings above 2.5 pointing to bearish sentiment and readings below 2.0 signaling a bullish mood. Vickers' current NYSE One-Week Sell/Buy Ratio is 1.89, while the Nasdaq ratio is 1.61. Vickers' Total One-Week Sell/Buy Ratio is now 1.69, bringing the Total Eight-Week Sell/Buy Ratio down to 3.69 from a recent high of around 5.00.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: HPQ, J, SPG, TJX, VNT
reports.reportTitle: As the market headed into the Thanksgiving-shortened trading week, the volume of insider transactions had risen to the highest level since November 2006, with almost 2,800 insider trades last week that met the criteria for inclusion in the Weekly Insider report from Vickers' Stock Research.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Simon Property Group, Inc.
reports.reportTitle: Simon Property Group Inc., based in Indianapolis, is a retail REIT that owns and leases malls and outlets. Simon owns or has interest in 233 properties with 191 million square feet of leasable space in North America, Asia, and Europe. Additionally, the company owns an 80% interest in the Taubman group and a 22% interest in Klepierre, a Paris-based real estate firm. SPG is a member of the S&P 500.

reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: September Bumpy, Insiders Calm
reports.reportTitle: Stock-market volatility has increased of late, leaving corporate insiders as whipsawed as any other investor. In the past few months, we've had weeks in which stocks pulled back. The insider-trading data from Vickers Stock Research tells us that insiders consistently used those weeks to swoop in and pick up shares. In follow-on weeks, when stocks stabilized near all-time highs, insiders pulled back on buying. Based on recent sell/buy data from Vickers, insiders remain more bullish than bearish. Vickers' benchmark NYSE/ASE One-Week Sell/Buy Ratio is currently 2.47. That's a neutral reading (improved from bearish last week); represents a third consecutive week of sentiment improvement; and compares very favorably to the 4.05 one-week ratio printed in early September. The NYSE/ASE eight-week moving average is 3.06 compared to 4.73 in mid-July. Overall, insider sentiment maintains a positive trend as the historically brutal month of September draws to a close and the historically positive last quarter of the year lies ahead.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Simon Property Group, Inc.
reports.reportTitle: Simon Property Group Inc., based in Indianapolis, is a retail REIT that owns and leases malls and outlets. Simon has an interest in or owns 234 properties with 191 million square feet of leasable space in North America, Asia, and Europe. It also has a 22% interest in Klepierre, a Paris-based real estate firm, which owns shopping centers in 15 European countries. SPG is a member of the S&P 500.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: SPG, BCE
reports.reportTitle: Stocks have declined broadly recently, as positive retail sales data and a better-than-expected inflation (CPI) report were unable to offset mounting investor concerns. These concerns include the still-heavy toll from COVID-19, signs of moderating economic growth, and worries on either side that a new tax bill will pass (the GOP) or won't make it through Congress (the Democrats). As well, investors are brooding over the potential implications to the global financial system should Evergrande, a giant Chinese property company, collapse.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: MU, SPG
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rose on Thursday morning on optimism about the Biden administration's $2 trillion infrastructure plan, despite concerns about higher taxes and clear opposition to the plan from House and Senate Republicans. Manufacturing data was strong. The Institute for Supply Management said that its national factory index rose to 64.7 in March from 60.8 in February. The reading topped the Reuters consensus forecast of 61.3 and was the strongest since December 1983. On the employment front, the Labor Department said that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 719,000 for the week ended March 27, up from 658,000 a week earlier and above the Bloomberg consensus forecast of 675,000. Continuing claims of 3.794 million also exceeded the consensus forecast, but were down from 3.87 million a week earlier. The Dow rose 0.3%, the S&P 0.8%, and the Nasdaq 1.5%. Crude oil rose slightly to $60 per barrel, while gold traded near $1730 per ounce.

reports.reportTitle: November was the best month on the S&P 500 since...April, when the index was up 12.7%. In this unprecedented year, you do not have to go back very far to find a blowout month.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: PANW, SLF, BBY, MDU, SPG
reports.reportTitle: Stocks were mixed on Wednesday morning amid strong earnings from Salesforce.com and new capital goods data. The Commerce Department said that orders for core capital goods excluding aircraft rose 1.9% in July, in line with the Reuters consensus forecast but down from 4.3% growth in June. Salesforce shares jumped 26% after the company posted strong fiscal 2Q results and raised its full-year revenue guidance. The Dow fell 0.3%, the S&P rose 0.4%, and the Nasdaq rose 1.0%. Crude oil traded near $43.50 per barrel, while gold rose $25 to $1948 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: BAX, SPG, ULTA, LB, M
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell sharply on Thursday morning amid concerns about rising coronavirus cases in many states and a bleak economic outlook from the Federal Reserve. First-time jobless claims totaled 1.542 million for the week ended June 6, down from the prior week and below the Reuters consensus of 1.55 million. The Dow fell 3.2%, the S&P 3.4%, and the Nasdaq 1.7%. Crude oil fell nearly 7% to $37 per barrel, while gold rose $29 to $1750 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CMG, ETH, IR, KLAC, MRK, MCHP, SPG
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rose on Thursday morning as China announced plans to lower tariffs on $75 billion of U.S. goods next Friday under the terms of the phase one trade deal signed last month. On the earnings front, Twitter shares soared more than 16%, despite lower-than-expected 4Q EPS, after the company posted $1 billion in quarterly revenue for the first time and strong growth in 'monetizable daily active users.' Bristol-Myers Squibb also rose strongly following much better than expected revenue and earnings. The Dow rose 0.1%, the S&P 0.3%, and the Nasdaq 0.4%. Crude oil rose slightly to $51 per barrel, while gold rose $4 to $1567 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: BKNG, CPRI, SPG, CVX, LGF/A, LYB, NYT
reports.reportTitle: The major indices are mixed at midday on Friday after President Trump reiterated that the United States has not yet agreed to any rollback of tariffs with China, re-igniting uncertainty about the status of a "phase one" trade deal. Disney shares gapped up this morning after a strong earnings report yesterday afternoon, with the media and entertainment company beating on both the top and bottom lines ahead of the launch of its new video streaming service. Industries doing well today include Entertainment, Biotechnology, and Household Durables. Industries showing weakness include Diversified Consumer Services, Metals & Mining, and Diversified Financial Services. The VIX is up 0.03 to 12.76 after the previous close of 12.73. The S&P was flat, the Dow fell 0.2%, and the Nasdaq rose 0.2%. Crude oil traded near $57 per barrel, while gold fell slightly to $1466 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: HUM, SPG, MRO
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rose strongly on Friday morning, led by the Financial and Technology sectors, as investors weighed a new round of earnings reports and July housing market data. The Commerce Department said that U.S. housing starts fell 4.0% to a seasonally adjusted 1.191 million last month, below the Reuters consensus forecast of 1.257 million. However, building permits rose 8.4%, the strongest gain since June 2017. Nvidia shares rose more than 8% after the chipmaker posted stronger-than-expected 2Q results. The S&P rose 1.4%, the Dow 1.1%, and the Nasdaq 1.6%. Crude oil rose slightly to about $55 per barrel, while gold fell $11 to $1520 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: The Argus High-Yield Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Growth stocks may be outperforming, again, in 2019. But in an environment of historically low interest rates (and with the Federal Reserve seemingly poised to cut again), many investors are still searching for high levels of income, which can often be found in value stocks. When we look for attractive high-yield/value stocks at Argus, we look for low valuations on metrics such as price/earnings, price/sales, price/book, yield and price/cash flow. But we also look for companies with clean balance sheets, high levels of profitability, cash-flow generation, and an experienced management teams. We seek to avoid companies in industries that are in secular decline, or with dividend yields that are so high that the payout is clearly at risk. That said, many value companies may face a substantial near-term industry problem. That might be a retailer fending off Amazon.com; or an energy company tied to the uncertain long-term outlook for demand for fossil fuels; or a newspaper company in the digital advertising age. Some value companies, such as tobacco companies, may face ongoing legal or regulatory risks. And others may be facing problems such as over-aggressive acquisitions, patent expirations or recent earnings stumbles. Based on requests from clients, we have designed a portfolio of companies followed by Argus Research that are BUY- or HOLD-rated on a long-term (five-year) basis and have an average yield of 4.0% or higher.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: VIAV, MET, RCL, SPG, GM, APO, CC
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rallied on Friday morning following a strong April employment report. The Labor Department said that the U.S. economy added 263,000 payroll jobs last month, up from a revised 189,000 in March and above the Reuters consensus forecast of 185,000. The official unemployment rate fell to 3.6% from 3.8% a month earlier. Average hourly wages rose 0.2% from the prior month, up from 0.1% growth in March, and 3.2% from the prior year. The S&P rose 0.8%, the Dow 0.6%, and the Nasdaq 1.2%. Crude oil rose slightly to $62 per barrel, while gold rose $11 to $1283 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: ILMN, NDAQ, NVS, CLS, EMR, GOOGL, RCL, SPG, STX, XOM
reports.reportTitle: January 2019 was the best month on the S&P 500 since January 2018. We all know what a strong January got us in 2018. Still, good Januarys generally are identified with better-than-average stock years. Since 1980 on the S&P 500, average capital appreciation for all years is 9.8%. For years in which January finished higher, however, the average gain is 15.2% -- even including the 6.2% decline (-4.4% with dividend) for 2018.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assesment: Bearish in the Short-Term
reports.reportTitle: The short-term momentum reading has weakened. This week, the percentage of stocks above their 20-day moving average fell to 20.2% from 77.6%, below the negative two standard deviation mark of 22.5%. This is now the worst that the reading has performed since late October. As such, it is currently in negative territory.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: BSX, CHKP, GD, LVS, MRK, MSFT, NOK, NSC, PKG, RTN, SPG, SWK, TROW, OC, KKR, TWTR
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rebounded on Thursday, helped by strong earnings reports, as investors sought bargains after Wednesday's massive selloff. On the economic front, the Commerce Department reported continued slow business spending on equipment, as orders for core capital goods fell 0.1% in September, below the Reuters consensus forecast of 0.5% growth. The Dow rose 1.63%, the S&P 1.86%, and the Nasdaq 2.95%. Crude oil rose slightly to trade near $67 per barrel, while gold rose $3 to $1,234 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Min Vol Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: With the stock market racing to new highs earlier this year, most mainstream investors were either looking to get aboard or stay aboard the galloping bull. As the market was lifted higher by the FAANG stocks, many investors likely became over-allocated to a couple of high risk-reward sectors. Even while riding the rally — and the recent ups and downs — some investors are considering end-of-rally strategies. Minimum volatility, or “Min Vol,” often falls into that defensive category.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: ILMN, SPG
reports.reportTitle: Vickers Stock Research, Argus' sister company, calculates proprietary Sell/Buy Ratios using data from recent Form-4 filings (through which insiders register purchases and sales of their stock with the SEC). Insiders are deemed to be in a bullish mood when the Sell/Buy Ratio comes in at 2.00 or below; they are neutral in the 2.00 to 2.50 range; and they are bearish if results are 2.50 or above.

reports.headHtml: Raising target by $5 to $200 on redevelopment
reports.reportTitle: Simon Property Group Inc., based in Indianapolis, is a retail REIT that owns and leases out its malls and outlets. Simon has an interest in or owns 234 properties with 191 million square feet of leasable space. It also has a 21% interest in Klepierre, a Paris-based real estate firm, which owns shopping centers in 16 European countries. SPG is a member of the S&P 500.

reports.headHtml: Raising target by $5 to $200 on redevelopment

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: ILMN, SPG
reports.reportTitle: Vickers Stock Research, Argus' sister company, calculates proprietary Sell/Buy Ratios using data from recent Form-4 filings (through which insiders register purchases and sales of their stock with the SEC). Insiders are deemed to be in a bullish mood when the Sell/Buy Ratio comes in at 2.00 or below; they are neutral in the 2.00 to 2.50 range; and they are bearish if results are 2.50 or above.

reports.headHtml: High Yield Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Growth stocks may be outperforming in 2018 -- but in an environment of historically low interest rates, many investors are still searching for high levels of income, which can often be found in Value stocks. Over the years, the performance record has favored Growth. Since 2003, the Russell 1000 Growth Index has climbed 423%, compared to an advance of 278% for the Russell 1000 Value Index. In 10 of the 15 years of this period, Growth stocks have topped Value stocks. Still, Value is the place to achieve income. The current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Value Index ETF is 2.2%, compared to the current yield on the iShares Russell 1000 Growth Index ETF of 1.1%. As well, sometimes the risk profile favors Value. For the past five years, the standard deviation of monthly returns for Value stocks has been 2.83%, compared to the standard deviation of monthly returns for Growth stocks of 2.93%. When we look for Value at Argus, we look for low valuations on metrics such as price/earnings, price/sales, price/book, yield and price/cash flow. But we also look for companies with clean balance sheets, high levels of profitability and cash flow generation capability, and experienced management teams.
